text: today on x cast italy's long
relationship with libya complicates its
role in NATO's mission stone tablets
along japan's coast trace a 600 year
history of tsunami warnings and a
reflection on the work of documentarian
and conflict photographer tim
hetherington killed Wednesday in misrata
Libya Italy on Wednesday decided to join
France and Britain in sending 10
advisors to help out the rebels in
eastern Libya this is one of the latest
steps that Italy has taken in order to
help the NATO intervention to oust
Colonel Qaddafi this has been actually a
very complicated role for Italy to play
Italy is the former colonial power in
Libya and has long-standing ties there
and billions of dollars in energy
contracts in Libya which provides a
quarter of Italy's natural gas now the
situation as a member of NATO and as a
country with close ties to Libya and to
Qaddafi has placed this government under
great strain in fact last week Prime
Minister Silvio Berlusconi told a group
of journalists that he was so reluctant
to have Italy joined the coalition to
oust Qaddafi that he considered
resigning and his advisers told him that
that was not a good idea he felt that he
had helped cultivate ties with Libya
over the years and that it was hardly
appropriate for Italy to be kind of on
on different sides of the issue here one
of the greatest consequences of the
Libya intervention for Italy is
immigration since the unrest began in
Tunisia in January thousands of
immigrants have left mostly Tunisia and
increasingly Libya on boats and headed
to Italy in recent day tensions between
Italy and France have been growing
extremely high because Italy has decided
to give temporary six-month residence
permits to many of these immigrants
who've come from Tunisia now Italy says
these permits are valid in the rest of
the European Union and France says no no
a residence permit in Italy doesn't mean
you can come to France and try to find
work and so the border between Italy and
France now is is rather tense and the
French are patrolling it quite you know
seriously to prevent
these immigrants who've come from Italy
into France so for now it seems like
some of the clearest collateral damage
as it were to come out of the Libya
intervention is the European Union
itself which is profoundly divided over
immigration over how to handle the
thousands of immigrants who are expected
to come from North Africa to Europe in
the coming weeks and months in Japan a
long history of tsunamis is documented
in stone one of the things I've seen
here as I've reported on the tsunami and
the aftermath in many of the town's they
have these stones that can be several
decades old or in some cases even
hundreds of years old which stand as
warnings about past tsunamis that have
struck here the stones often contain
very simple instructions of what to do
during a tsunami for example if there's
a large earthquake hit the high ground
one of the most interesting of you
stones is located in a town called Ana
Yoshi a very small village of 34 people
and it's perfectly in fact stone says do
not build below at this point and the
stone itself sits about a mile inland
and interesting thing is the waters
actually reached about 300 feet shy of
the stone if you go beyond the stone
towards to see it's just complete and
total devastation the warnings allow the
stone seemed to have gone unheeded there
was the sense that modern construction
and concrete wave walls could protect
the towns from tsunamis and these all
proved completely ineffectual one of the
lessons that's come out of this tsunami
is the value of the old teaching that
these modern concrete wave walls
couldn't stop the tsunami about this old
sort of folklore teaching if there's a
big earthquake go to high ground it
turns out that that was the most
effective thing for saving lives and on
Wednesday in Misurata Libya three
photographers were injured and conflict
photographer and documentarian Tim
Hetherington was killed Hetherington is
probably best known for his
oscar-nominated documentary restrepo
about the war in Afghanistan
in june two thousand and ten times
photographer michael camber interviewed
hetherington about the philosophy behind
his dangerous work I'm not interested in
photography as the implication that it's
shot and is still this photographic
camera is that what I'm giving you is
I'm giving you an image with the
implication that this is authentic that
this has happened and that it hasn't
been it the image represents something
that actually happened in real life that
is the most important relationship with
the audience and that's something that's
true Tim Hetherington was 40
